item.title: Foreigners’ Interest in US Job Postings Slumps in Indeed Data
item.description: The burst of foreign interest in US jobs following the Covid-19 pandemic has all but vanished, a shift that threatens to exacerbate labor shortages in industries such as health care.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan, Augusta Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Registered nurses care for patients in Torrance, California, in 2021. Photographer: Mario Tama/Getty Images

item.title: Nomura Turns Bullish on China’s Stocks After Trade Truce With US
item.description: Nomura Holdings Inc. strategists upgraded Chinese stocks to a ‘tactical overweight,’ saying the trade truce between the US and China is a significant positive for the Asian nation’s equities.
item.dc:creator: Abhishek Vishnoi

media:content.media:description: Signage outside a branch of Nomura Securities Co. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: BOJ Still Eyeing Rate Hikes While Wary of Tariffs, Summary Shows
item.description: Bank of Japan board members signaled their intention for further rate hikes while citing the need to stay vigilant due the potential economic impacts from US tariff measures, according to a summary of opinions from their April 30-May 1 meeting.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: A Japanese flag flies outside the Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo.

item.title: Tariffs Create World Challenges, Opportunities, WTO Head Says
item.description: The global trade war with its persistent barrage of tariff developments provides both challenges and opportunities, according to Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, the Director General of the World Trade Organisation.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala Photographer: Samuel Corum/Bloomberg

item.title: Australia’s Business Conditions Ease, Boosting Case for RBA Cuts
item.description: Australian business conditions eased in April as profitability weakened, forward orders slipped and firms’ spending plans took a hit, boosting the case for the Reserve Bank to cut interest rates to support the economy.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Bond Traders Eye Inflation for Rate Clues as Recession Odds Fade
item.description: The temporary US-China trade truce dimmed the odds of a recession and sparked a selloff in Treasuries, raising the stakes for investors ahead of the release of inflation figures for the world’s biggest economy.
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick

item.title: US Inflation Seen Picking Up in April With Modest Tariffs Impact
item.description: US inflation likely accelerated in April after an unexpected cooldown the previous month, with higher tariffs on Chinese goods in particular starting to impact prices.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva

item.title: New Yorkers Vow to Block House GOP Tax Bill Over SALT Limit
item.description: Two New York Republican lawmakers promised to block their party’s signature tax legislation unless GOP leaders raise a proposed $30,000 limit on the federal income tax deduction for state and local taxes.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Nacha Cattan

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC.

item.title: Lula and Xi to Ink New Deals as Brazil Shrugs Off Trump’s Trade Threats
item.description: Brazil’s Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva insists he doesn’t want to pick between the US and China as his two largest trading partners wage a trade war. But it’s increasingly clear which side he’d choose if forced.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, Leonardo Lara, Daniel Carvalho

media:content.media:description: Xi Jinping and Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva in 2024.

item.title: SALT, Tips and Auto Loans: A Guide to the House GOP Tax Bill
item.description: House Republicans’ release of the tax provisions in their massive fiscal bill provides a crucial initial reading of what party leaders think could pass, culminating weeks of intense negotiations among fractious GOP lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Emily Birnbaum

media:content.media:description: Customers at a Ford dealership in Richmond, California, US, on Wednesday, April 16, 2025. US retail sales rose substantially in March on a jump in car purchases and other goods such as electronics, suggesting consumers were scrambling to get ahead of tariffs.

item.title: US-China Truce Likely to Avert Recession But Not Coming Slowdown
item.description: The Trump administration’s temporary trade deal with China didn’t arrive in time to prevent a slowdown in the US economy, forecasters say, even if it reduces the risk of a full-blown recession later this year.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard, Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: The YM Welcome container ship docked at the Port of Long Beach in Long Beach, California, US, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Since the US raised levies on China to 145% in early April, cargo shipments have plummeted, perhaps by as much as 60%, according to one estimate.

item.title: GOP to Phase Out Biden Energy Credits to Pay for Tax Cuts
item.description: House Republicans are proposing to eliminate a tax credit for electric vehicles and phase out incentives to develop clean-energy projects to help pay for President Donald Trump’s massive tax package.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: A driver unplugs an electric vehicle charging station in Hudson, New York.

item.title: Traders See Fed Cutting Rates Just Twice in 2025 on Cooling Trade War
item.description: Traders lowered their bets on the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate cuts this year, pricing in just two reductions for 2025 after the US and China agreed to cut tariffs and moderate their trade war.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie

item.title: Alberta Freezes Industrial Carbon Tax to Help Firms as Tariffs Hurt Economy
item.description: Alberta is freezing its industrial carbon tax in a bid to help companies struggling with the effects of US tariffs, potentially setting up a challenge to the government of Prime Minister Mark Carney.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Orland

media:content.media:description: An oil refinery in Burnaby, British Columbia.

item.title: Fed’s Kugler Sees Significant Tariff Impact Despite Recent News
item.description: Federal Reserve Governor Adriana Kugler said the Trump administration’s tariff policies are likely to boost inflation and weigh on economic growth, even with the recently announced reduction in levies on China.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Adriana Kugler

item.title: State AI Regulation Ban Tucked Into Republican Tax, Fiscal Bill
item.description: A powerful House committee has tucked language preventing states from regulating artificial intelligence into President Donald Trump’s massive tax and spending bill, a move that would benefit many of the US’s largest tech and AI companies.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum

media:content.media:description: A technician types questions into a program used to test and develop artificial intelligence programs.

item.title: ECB’s Kazaks Sees Reason for Another Rate Cut, But Urges Caution
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Martins Kazaks urged for caution even as he backed a further reduction in borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Eglitis

media:content.media:description: Martins Kazaks

item.title: US Tariff Revenue Jumped in April, Before China De-Escalation
item.description: The US collected a record amount of revenue from tariffs in April, helping to limit a further widening of the budget deficit, though President Donald Trump’s search for trade deals with targeted nations may scale back future amounts collected.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Port of Long Beach in Long Beach, California, US, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Since the US raised levies on China to 145% in early April, cargo shipments have plummeted, perhaps by as much as 60%, according to one estimate.

item.title: Italy’s ESM Refusal Adds Risk Factor, Top EU Officials Warn
item.description: Italy’s failure to ratify the European Stability Mechanism bailout fund leaves the bloc with less protection in case of a future banking crisis, top officials warned.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio, Daniel Basteiro, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: The European Stability Mechanism office building in Luxembourg.

item.title: World Bank Sees Nigeria’s Revenues Surging If Import Bans Lifted
item.description: Lifting Nigeria’s high tariffs and import bans could significantly increase tax revenue for Africa’s most populous country, the World Bank said.
item.dc:creator: Nduka Orjinmo

media:content.media:description: Stalls selling textiles, consumer goods and electronics line an area of Utako Ultra Modern market in Abuja, Nigeria, on Wednesday, June 3, 2020. The government of Nigeria, whose revenue could be slashed by more than half this year due to the oil-price slump, finalized plans for a revised budget that keeps spending almost intact, and that will mean more borrowing.

item.title: BOE’s Taylor Warns of ‘Perilous’ Trade Threat After Urging Big Rate Cut
item.description: Bank of England policymaker Alan Taylor said interest rates are still a “long way” from moving out of restrictive levels, warning of the “perilous” threat from Donald Trump’s trade war.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Philip Aldrick, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: A container ship at the Port of Felixstowe Ltd. in Felixstowe, UK.

item.title: Market Doubts on Dollar Are Chance for EU, ESM Chief Says
item.description: A top European Union policymaker said the region should take advantage of investor doubts in the dollar and US Treasuries.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze, Jorge Valero, Alessandra Migliaccio, Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: Pierre Gramegna, managing director of the European Stability Mechanism (ESM), during a news conference following a Eurogroup meeting in Brussels, Belgium, on Monday, May 12, 2025. With the euro charting a course for its best year in two decades and asset managers like Amundi SA flipping from bear to bull, Europe's currency is undergoing a resurgence that's rarely been seen at any point since its creation in 1999. Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB Must Be Cautious on Next Rate Steps, Nagel and Escriva Say
item.description: The European Central Bank must be careful in deciding on its next interest-rate moves given high uncertainty about President Donald Trump’s economic policies, according to two Governing Council members.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

item.title: IMF Plans Kenya Debt Sustainability Study Ahead of New Deal
item.description: The International Monetary Fund plans an in-depth review of Kenya’s debt to determine the nation’s financing needs under a new program.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: IMF branding.

item.title: Americans Hit the Road as Economic Fears Discourage Flying
item.description: Kristin Herman and her partner had been planning a European getaway with stops in Paris and Rome, but with the US economy suddenly wobbling, the couple instead drove to Oregon’s nearby redwood forests and Cannon Beach — even camping some nights to save on hotels.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Nathan Risser

media:content.media:description: Traffic moves along Interstate 80 in Emeryville, California, US, on Wednesday, Nov. 27, 2024. AAA projects 79.9 million travelers will head 50 miles or more from home over the Thanksgiving holiday travel period. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Senegal Seeks to Woo $1.7 Billion Investment for Digital Economy
item.description: Senegalese President Bassirou Diomaye Faye seeks to attract $1.7 billion of investments to build digital infrastructure and create more job opportunities for the country’s youth.
item.dc:creator: Yinka Ibukun

media:content.media:description: Bassirou Diomaye Faye, Senegal’s president, speaks during his inauguration ceremony in Diamniadio, Senegal, on Tuesday, April 2, 2024. Senegal’s opposition politician Faye was sworn in as president on Tuesday, becoming the youngest elected African leader less than three weeks after he was released from prison to run in the election last month.

item.title: US Said to Welcome EU Proposal to Cooperate on Economic Security
item.description: The US has welcomed European Union proposals to cooperate on mutual investments and economic security challenges, while continuing to provide little clarity on the possible outcomes of trade negotiations between the two sides, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Employees work on a VW Golf on the assembly line at the Volkswagen AG factory in Wolfsburg, Germany, on Thursday, May 23, 2024. Auto sales in Europe rose 12% in April as manufacturers including Volkswagen AG and Renault SA benefited from robust demand for plug-in and conventional cars in several major markets.

item.title: Detained Duterte Set for Mayoral Win Ahead of ICC Trial in Hague
item.description: Ex-Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is leading in the local election in his clan’s stronghold south of the country, even as he awaits trial in the Netherlands for alleged crimes against humanity.
item.dc:creator: Andreo Calonzo

media:content.media:description: Rodrigo Duterte during a campaign rally in Hong Kong on March 9.

item.title: Romanian Bond Sale Lures Investors After Yield Jump as Leu Gains
item.description: Romania managed to attract solid demand in a domestic bond sale but the funding came at an increased price as political risks before the presidential run-off continued to weigh on investors’ perception.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca, Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: The parliament building during parliamentary elections, in Bucharest, Romania, on Sunday, Dec. 1, 2024. In the final days before Romania’s parliamentary elections this weekend, the governing parties’ leaders both quit, pollsters gave up on projecting the results and the nation’s top court cast serious doubt on the integrity of the voting process.

item.title: UK and EU Haggle Over Fish and Food Days Before Reset Summit
item.description: Britain and the European Union are still trying to resolve disagreements over fisheries and food checks just a week before a summit in London where Prime Minister Keir Starmer plans to announce a major reset in post-Brexit relations.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Jorge Valero, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Fishermen in the English Channel from the Port of Newhaven.
